text.0: Everyone [may] slaughter and his slaughter is valid: except  a deafmute, a simpleton or a minor, so that they will not spoil the slaughter. But [if they] all slaughter and others see them, their slaughter is valid.

1.0: The Holy One does not even allow a righteous person’s animal to sin, so much more so the tsadiq himself.

2.0: An individual does not [so much as] bruise his finger below [i.e. on earth], unless it is so ordained by above [in Heaven], as it says, The steps of man are guided by the L-rd
2.1: “This poor [animal] is going to do the will of her Possessor (God), and you feed her t’veilim?!”

3.0: Mishna: One who slaughters on Shabbat or on Yom Kippur, even though he's liable for his soul, his slaughtering is Kosher.
3.1: Gamarra: Rav Huna says that Hiiya bar Rav expounded in the name of Rav, [that this slaughtered animal] is forbidden to eat on the day. The Yeshiva Bochrim in the academy came to think that this ruling of rag reflects the view of Rabbi Yehuda. Which of Rabbi Yehuda's mishnayot? It's Rabbi Yehuda about preparation. For it was taught in a mishnah that one can chop up gourds for an animal, or a carcass for a dogs. But Rabbi Yehuda says that if it wasn't a carcass as of shabbat eve, then it's forbidden...

4.0: Mishnah: In the case where one is obligated [in tithing] in bitter almonds they are exempt from sweet ones, when they are obligated in sweet ones, they are exempt from bitter ones.
4.1: Gemarra: The rabbis taught in a beraita, Almonds that are bitter and small are obligated. Big ones are exempt. Sweet ones that are big are obligated, while the small ones are exempt. Rabbi Yishmael in the name of Rabbi Yossi says in the name of his father: Both this one and that one are exempt. And some say [that he said] both this and this are obligated. Rabbi Ilai says....
4.2: Mishnah: The grape seeds that did not ferment, are not able to be redeemed with silver of tithe money, and they invalidate a mikvah. Once it ferments, it can be redeemed on silver of tithe money and does not invalidate a mikvah. Brothers that are in a partnership, when they are obligated in the Kalbon [extra bit on the shekel] they are exempt from the first born animal tithe, when they are obligated in  the first born animal tithe, then they are obligated in Kalbon.
4.3: Germara: Who is the author of our mishnah? It is not Rabbi Yehuda, nor is it the Rabbis. For it was taught in a Beraita, one who has temed and adds water in a certain quantity, and then [when removing the temed] finds it as it's [original] volume, he is exempt [from tithing], But Rabbi Yehudah obligates him [to tithe]. Who is it [the author of our mishnah] ? If it's the Rabbis, even though it fermented [they would still exempt him], if it was Rabbi Yehudah, even though it did not ferment [he would obligate in tithing].  Rabbi Nachman says in the name of Rabba Bar Avuah.

5.1: It is permissible to eat eggs that were boiled with non-kosher eggs [based on Rashi]
5.2: Eggs that were not fertilized - a concerned soul will eat them.
5.3: If there is a blood spot inside the egg, remove the blood and eat the remainder.
5.5: This is the case where the blood spot is on its knot [place of fertilization.]
5.6: Dostei father of R' Aptoriki taught
5.7: This was only taught when it [the blood spot] was located in the egg white but if it is on the egg yolk, even the whole egg is forbidden. What is the reason?
5.9: Rav Gavia from Bay Katil said to Rav Ashi
5.10: The opposite ruling [the blood spot on the yolk and white] was taught before Abbaya and Abbaya corrected it to our version.

6.1: In the merit that our father Abraham said

7.0: "whether from a string to a shoe strap" (Genesis 14:23) his sons merited to two commandments - to the string of techelet and the strap of phylacteries...
7.1: I can understand [why] the strap of tefillin [is cast as a reward], it is written
7.2: (Deut. 28:10) "And all the nations of the land will see that the name of God is called over you," and it is taught in a baraita Rabbi Eliezer the great says,
7.4: but what of the string of techelet?
7.5: That it was taught, Rabbi Meir
7.6: says what distinguished techelet from all the colors?
7.7: Because techelet is similar to the sea, and the sea is similar to the firmament, and the firmament is similar to a sapphire stone, and a sapphire stone is similar to the throne of Glory, as it is written
7.8: "And they saw the God of Israel, and under his legs...", and it is written
7.9: "and like the appearance of the sapphire stone the likeness of the throne.

8.1: ‘I once asked R’ Gamliel and R’ Yehoshua in the meatmarket of Emmaus where they had gone to buy an animal for the wedding feast of R’ Gamliel's son: It is written, “And the sun rose for him..” (Bereshit 32:32) Did the sun rise only for him? Did it not rise for whole world?
8.3: ‘The sun which had set for his sake, rose for his sake, as it is written “And Jacob left Beer sheba, and he went to Haran.” (Bereshit 28:10) And it is further written “And he arrived at the place…” (Bereshit 28:11) When he reached Haran he said to himself,
8.4: ‘Is it possible that I passed the lace where my fathers prayed and I did not pray?’
8.5: He immediately resolved to return, and the earth contracted and he immediately arrived at the place.
8.6: After he prayed he wanted to return to Haran, but the Holy One said
8.7: ‘This righteous man has come to my lodging, shall he leave without a night's rest?’
8.9: It is written “…and he took of the stones of the place…” (Bereshit 28:11) but it is also written “…and he took the stone…” (Bereshit 28:18)
8.11: ‘This teaches that all the stones gathered together into one place and each one said: let the righteous one rest his head on me!’
8.14: “And he dreamed, and behold! a ladder set up on the ground…” (Bereshit 28:12) A Tanna taught:
8.15: What was the width of the ladder? Eight thousand parasangs, as it is written “…and behold, angels of God were ascending and descending upon it.” (ibid.) At least two were ascending and two descending, and when they met each other on the ladder there were four; and about an angel it is written “His body was like tarshish…” (Daniel 10:6) and we have a tradition that the Tarshish is two thousand parasangs long.
8.17: They ascended to look at the image above and descended to look at the image below. ...
8.18: They wished to hurt him, when “And behold, the Lord was standing over him…” (Bereshit 28:13) R’ Shimon ben Lakish said
8.19: ‘were it not expressly stated in the Scripture, we would not dare to say it. God is made to appear like a man who is fanning his son.
8.20: “…the land upon which you are lying to you I will give it and to your seed.” (ibid.) What is the greatness of this?
8.22: ‘this teaches that the Holy One folded up the whole of the land of Israel and put it under our father Yaakov, in order that it be easily conquered by his descendants.

9.0: Mishnah: A thigh in which the sciatic nerve was cooked, if it has [enough] to give flavor [to the thigh], this [thigh] is forbidden.
9.1: How do we measure it? Like meat [cooked] with a turnip.
9.2: A sciatic nerve that was cooked with other nerves, at a time when one [still] recognizes it, [the standard for forbidding] is when it gives flavor. If [it is] not [recognized], all of it is forbidden. And [in] broth, when it gives flavor.
9.3: And so too with a piece of a nevelah [an improperly slaughtered animal of a permitted species], and so too with a piece of prohibited fish which was cooked with [other] pieces: at a time when one recognized them, [the standard] is when it gives flavor; and if [it is] not [recognized], they are all forbidden. And for the broth [the standard] is when it gives flavor.
9.5: This is only taught when it's boiled [with the nerve] in, but if it's roasted [with the nerve] in, peel and eat until you get to the nerve.

10.0: Rav Acha bar Rav asked Ravina, what's your understanding of what Shmuel says:
10.1: "Salted is like hot, pickled is like cooked", and Shmuel says:
10.2: "This is only taught when it's boiled [with the nerve] in, but if it's roasted [with the nerve] in, peel and eat until you get to the nerve."

11.1: How long should one wait between [eating] meat and cheese?
11.5: One who eats meat isn't allowed to eat cheese, [one who eats] cheese is allowed to eat meat.
11.6: Rather [Rav Asi must have asked] How long should one wait between [eating] cheese and meat?...
11.9: Regarding what we quoted above "Rav Chisda said,
11.10: One who eats meat isn't allowed to eat cheese,
11.11: [one who eats] cheese is allowed to eat meat."
11.12: Rav Aha bar Yosef said to Rav Chisda,
11.13: "The meat this is between the teeth, what do we make of it?"
11.14: We reference the verse, "The meat was still between their teeth" (Numbers 11:33)
11.16: In comparison to my father, regarding this matter, I am vinegar the son of wine.   My father, when he ate meat, would not eat cheese until the same time the next day.
11.17: But I, even if I won't eat it at this meal, I'll eat it at the next meal.

12.0: [this demon entity] saw that they were spilling water out from the mouth of the pitcher, saying
12.1: ...If I knew that you had the custom to do this, I would not have delayed
12.2: Upon Rav Dimi's coming he said;
12.3: ... [failing to do] The first waters fed him pig meat, the last removed a woman from her husband
12.5: ...[Failing to do] The first waters fed him neveilah meat, the last killed somebody
12.6: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said; and your mnemonic [is this]
12.7: Rav Dimi came [the husband] removed her; Ravin came [and] killed her
12.8: ... R' Abba taught; one of these [is not] and one of these [is] reflecting the most [more] severe
12.9: ...It was told [about water] heated by fire
12.11: ...We cannot use them to wash the hands. But R'Yochanan said:
12.12: We can use them to wash the hands
12.14: I asked of Rabban Gamliel the son of Rebbi, and he was the one who ate only tohoros and he said to me:
12.15: All the great of Galil do so
12.16: the Hot springs of Tiberias; Chizkiyah said
12.17: We cannot use them to wash hands, but we can immerse hands in them.
12.19: One may immerse his whole body in [the springs], but not his face, hands and feet.
12.20: ...Now if one can immerse [submerge] his whole body in them, it is not certain [about] his face, hands and feet
12.22: ...When they are in their place all agree that it is permitted

13.0: ... (M') [If] A drop of milk falls on a slice of meat and imparts a flavor to it, prohibited.
13.1: If it falls into a [meat] soup and imparts a flavor, prohibited.
13.3: ... [The issue of] Taste without the object [giving off the taste] is, in general, [prohibited] by the Torah. And if you should think that it is [only prohibited] by the Rabbis [and that the reason] that we don't learn it from [the prohibition of not mixing] meat and milk is because it is a new  case. But if this is a new case then it wouldn't matter about if it imparted taste [or not].
13.5: ...[only] cooking was prohibited by the Torah.
13.7: ...When the contact happens and the taste is transferred the mixture is forbidden like neveilah which can in turn render other pieces [of meat] prohibited, because they are the same type of substance.

14.0: Says Rav Yehuda in the name of Shmuel:
14.1: It's prohibited to eat hot food in a dish that was used to salt meat.
14.2: and Shmuel is self consistent, since he says:
14.3: "Salted is like hot, pickled is like cooked."

15.0: [...] There was a bird that fell into a jar of kamka [milk based food]. Rav Hinena bar Rava of Pashrona permitted it.
15.2: Who is wise enough to permit in this way if not Rav Hinena bar Rava of Pashrona!
15.4: When Shmuel said "Salted is like hot...", it's only when it can't be eaten because of its saltiness. This kutcha [=kamka] can be eaten even with its saltiness.
15.5: And this statement is when it's raw, but roasted, it needs [removal of] a peel.
15.6: And if it has cracks, the whole thing is prohibited. and it it's spiced, it's prohibited.

16.0: Assume that it derives from Shmuel, who said:
16.1: "Salted is like hot, pickled is like cooked."

17.0: Where is Moses indicated in the Torah?
17.1: In the verse: For that he also is flesh.
17.2: Where is Haman indicated in the Torah?
17.3: In the verse: Is it [hamin] from the tree?
17.4: Where is Esther indicated in the Torah?
17.5: [In the verse,] And I will surely hide [asthir] my face.
17.6: Where is Mordecai indicated in the Torah?
17.7: In the verse: Flowing myrrh,20 which the Targum renders
